lessons.title: Travel and Tourism Vocabulary

body.content: In a business setting, it's important to introduce yourself professionally. A proper introduction sets the tone for your business relationships.

body.transcript: Hello, my name is John Smith. I'm a senior manager at ABC Corporation, specializing in digital marketing.

lines.speaker: Person A
lines.text: Hello, I'm Sarah Johnson from Marketing.

lines.speaker: Person B
lines.text: Nice to meet you, Sarah. I'm Tom from Sales.

lines.speaker: Person A
lines.text: It's great to meet you too. What's your area of focus?

lines.speaker: Person B
lines.text: I primarily handle enterprise clients and large accounts.

body.content: Professional email writing is a crucial skill in the business world. Your emails represent you and your organization.

body.caption: Example of a well-formatted business email

lines.speaker: Email Template
lines.text:
Dear Mr. Johnson,

I hope this email finds you well. I am writing to follow up on our discussion regarding the Q3 marketing strategy.

Best regards,
Alex Chen

body.content: Conference calls are a regular part of modern business. Understanding proper etiquette ensures professional communication.

body.transcript: Good morning everyone. Thank you for joining today's conference call. We have a lot to cover.

body.content: Traveling to a new country can be exciting but also challenging. Learning common airport phrases will help you navigate with confidence.

body.transcript:
Passenger: Good morning. I'd like to check in for my flight to London, please.
Agent: Of course. May I see your passport and ticket?

lines.speaker: Agent
lines.text: Will you be checking any luggage today?

lines.speaker: Passenger
lines.text: Yes, I have two bags.

lines.speaker: Agent
lines.text: That will be fine. Here are your boarding passes.

body.content: Booking a hotel can be easy once you know the right phrases and vocabulary. This lesson covers everything from reservations to check-in.

body.transcript:
Receptionist: Good evening. Welcome to the Grand Hotel. Do you have a reservation?
Guest: Yes, I have a booking under the name Wilson for three nights.

lines.speaker: Receptionist
lines.text: Could you fill in this registration form, please?

lines.speaker: Guest
lines.text: Of course. What information do you need?

lines.speaker: Receptionist
lines.text: Your full name, address, and passport number will suffice.

body.content: Dining out while traveling is a wonderful experience. Learn the vocabulary and phrases needed to order food at restaurants.

body.transcript:
Waiter: Good evening. How many guests are dining with us tonight?
Customer: Good evening. There are four of us. Do you have a table available?

lines.speaker: Waiter
lines.text: Are you ready to order, or do you need more time?

lines.speaker: Customer
lines.text: I'd like the grilled salmon with vegetables, please.

lines.speaker: Waiter
lines.text: Excellent choice. And to drink?

lines.speaker: Customer
lines.text: I'll have a glass of white wine, please.

body.content: The present simple tense is used for facts, habits, and regular occurrences. It's the foundation of English grammar.
usage: Habits: I drink coffee every morning
Regular events: They play tennis on Fridays

body.caption: Present Simple Tense formation and examples

body.transcript: Affirmative: I play tennis. Negative: I do not play tennis. Question: Do you play tennis?

body.content: Past tenses in English can be tricky. This lesson covers the simple past, past continuous, past perfect, and past perfect continuous.

lines.speaker: Teacher
lines.text: When did you arrive in London?

lines.speaker: Student
lines.text: I arrived last Monday.

lines.speaker: Teacher
lines.text: What were you doing when I called?

lines.speaker: Student
lines.text: I was studying for my exam.

body.content: Casual conversations are more relaxed than formal ones. Learn how to engage in natural, everyday English conversations.

lines.speaker: Person A
lines.text: Hey, how are you doing?

lines.speaker: Person B
lines.text: I'm good, thanks. How about you?

lines.speaker: Person A
lines.text: Pretty well. Did you catch the game last night?

lines.speaker: Person B
lines.text: Yeah, it was amazing! What did you think?

body.transcript: Two native speakers discuss travel plans, using natural pronunciation and colloquial expressions.
Native speakers discussing workplace challenges and professional development opportunities.

body.content: Business vocabulary is essential for professional success. Master terms related to finance, management, HR, and operations.

lines.speaker: Manager
lines.text: We need to increase our ROI by 15% this quarter.

lines.speaker: Team Lead
lines.text: We can achieve that by optimizing our supply chain and cutting overhead costs.

lines.speaker: Manager
lines.text: Good. Prepare a proposal for the quarterly board meeting.

body.content: Travel vocabulary includes terms for accommodations, transportation, attractions, and experiences. Expand your ability to discuss travel scenarios.

lines.speaker: Tourist
lines.text: Excuse me, how do I get to the main tourist information center?

lines.speaker: Local
lines.text: It's about two blocks down this street, on your left. You can't miss it.

lines.speaker: Tourist
lines.text: Great, thanks! Are there any popular attractions nearby?

lines.speaker: Local
lines.text: Yes, the old cathedral is just behind the information center. It's definitely worth visiting.

flashcard_sets.title: Phrasal Verbs Collection
flashcard_sets.description: Common phrasal verbs used in everyday English

flashcard_sets.title: Idioms You Should Know
flashcard_sets.description: Popular English idioms and their meanings

flashcards.back_text: Return On Investment - a measure of financial performance
The final date or time by which something must be completed
Using resources strategically to achieve maximum effect with minimum effort
Any person or organization with an interest in a business or project
The interaction of elements that produce a combined effect greater than the sum of individual elements
Ensuring that business activities are aligned with the organization's strategy and goals

flashcards.front_text: What do you say when checking luggage at the airport?
flashcards.back_text: Do you have any luggage to check? / I have two bags to check.

flashcards.front_text: How do you ask for a room with a view at a hotel?
flashcards.back_text: Could I have a room with a view? / Do you have any rooms with a view available?

flashcards.front_text: What's a common way to ask for directions?
flashcards.back_text: Excuse me, how do I get to...? / Could you direct me to...?

flashcards.front_text: What does 'break down' mean as a phrasal verb?
flashcards.back_text: To stop functioning; to analyze into components; to reduce into smaller parts
To cancel or postpone something that was planned
To solve a problem; to understand something; to calculate
To start a conversation or make someone feel comfortable in a new situation
No matter what the weather or circumstances are; definitely

flashcards.front_text: Explain 'cost an arm and a leg'

quizzes.title: Office Introductions Quiz
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge of professional office introductions

quizzes.title: Business Email Writing Quiz
quizzes.description: Assess your professional email writing skills

quizzes.title: Airport Conversations Quiz
quizzes.description: Test your airport-related vocabulary and phrases

quizzes.title: Present Simple Tense Quiz
quizzes.description: Quiz on present simple tense formation and usage

quizzes.title: Past Tenses Quiz
quizzes.description: Test your understanding of all past tenses

quiz_questions.prompt: What is the correct way to introduce yourself in a business meeting?

metadata.hint: Start with a greeting and your full name

quiz_questions.prompt: My name is ____ and I work in the Marketing department.
How should you greet your boss in a formal setting?

metadata.hint: Use their title and last name

quiz_questions.prompt: Which phrases are appropriate for a professional introduction? (Select all that apply)

correct_answers: I'm pleased to make your acquaintance

quiz_questions.prompt: I would like to ____ myself. I'm the new project manager.
What should be the first line of a professional email?
Dear ____, I hope this email finds you well.
How should you end a formal business email?
What is the purpose of the subject line in an email?

metadata.hint: It should be clear and concise

quiz_questions.prompt: I am writing to ____ on our meeting from last week.
What should you avoid in professional emails?
What do you say at the airport check-in counter?
I have a booking under the name ____.
How many bags are you checking?
Do I have a ____ seat?
The simple present is used for:
He ____ (go) to work every day.
Form the negative: 'I like pizza'
Do you ____ (understand) English?
Which past tense is used for a completed action at a specific time?
I ____ (go) to the store yesterday.
What does past continuous express?

metadata.hint: An action in progress at a specific past time

quiz_questions.prompt: When you called, I ____ (watch) a movie.
Use past perfect: By the time she arrived, I ____

metadata.hint: An action completed before another past action

quiz_questions.prompt: Form the question: 'Did you go to the party?'

question_options.label: Hello, I'm [Your Name] from [Department]
question_options.feedback: Correct! This is a professional and clear introduction.

question_options.label: Hey, what's up?
question_options.feedback: Too casual for a business setting.

question_options.label: Just call me by my first name
question_options.feedback: While friendly, this doesn't provide complete information.

question_options.label: Dear Sir/Madam
question_options.feedback: Too formal and outdated for most business settings.

question_options.label: Mr./Ms. [Last Name]
question_options.feedback: Correct! This shows respect and is appropriate in formal settings.

question_options.label: [First Name]
question_options.feedback: May be too informal depending on the context.

question_options.label: A greeting followed by your name and purpose
question_options.feedback: Excellent! This structure immediately sets a professional tone.

question_options.label: A joke to break the ice
question_options.feedback: Not recommended for professional emails.

question_options.label: Casual greeting like 'Hey'
question_options.feedback: Too informal for professional communication.

question_options.label: Best regards
question_options.feedback: Correct! This is a professional and widely accepted closing.

question_options.label: Your buddy
question_options.feedback: Far too casual for business emails.

question_options.label: Cheers
question_options.feedback: Too informal for formal business communication.

question_options.label: To make the email visually appealing
question_options.feedback: The subject line serves a more practical purpose.

question_options.label: To summarize the email content and help with organization
question_options.feedback: Correct! A clear subject line helps recipients understand and organize emails.

question_options.label: It's not really important
question_options.feedback: Subject lines are crucial for professional communication.

question_options.label: Good afternoon, I'd like to check in for my flight.
question_options.feedback: Perfect! This is polite and clear at the airport.

question_options.label: I'm getting on your plane.
question_options.feedback: Too informal for the airport environment.

question_options.label: Where's the counter?
question_options.feedback: This doesn't indicate your purpose.

question_options.label: For habits and regular routines
question_options.feedback: Correct! Simple present is perfect for describing habits and routines.

question_options.label: For past events only
question_options.feedback: Simple present is for current actions and habits, not past events.

question_options.label: For future plans only
question_options.feedback: Simple present describes regular actions, not specifically future plans.

question_options.label: Simple past
question_options.feedback: Correct! Simple past is used for completed actions at a specific time.

question_options.label: Past continuous
question_options.feedback: Past continuous is for actions in progress during a past period.

question_options.label: Present perfect
question_options.feedback: Present perfect connects past and present, not specific past time.

question_options.label: An action at a specific moment in the past
question_options.feedback: That's simple past, not past continuous.

question_options.label: An action in progress at a specific past time
question_options.feedback: Excellent! This is exactly what past continuous expresses.

question_options.label: A repeated action in the past
question_options.feedback: That would be simple past with frequency indicators.
